abstract.t: It has become clear that a number of users would like to use the DNS resolution system for "internal" names or names which do not have meaning in the global context. This document reserves the string ".internal" for this purpose.

[ Ed note: Text inside square brackets ([]) is additional background information, answers to frequently asked questions, general musings, etc. They will be removed before publication. RFC Editor: Please remove these before publication. ]

[ This document is being collaborated on in Github at: https://github.com/__URL__. The most recent version of the document, open issues, etc should all be available here. The authors (gratefully) accept pull requests ]

[ Ed note: This document is intended to drive discussion. It is clear that there has been a desire for an RFC1918-type TLD for a long time; in its absence, people have just started using whatever seemed convenient. This document (which may be controversial) requests that the allocation of .internal for this use. There is no existing process for this - some of the purpose of this document is to explore the process implications, etc. ]

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Over the years, a number of strings have been used as pseudo-TLDs for namespaces that disjoint from the "global" namespace - examples of these include .home, .corp, .mail. See , for more background information on this issue. The document discusses the issues in depth, and should be considered required reading for understanding this document.

The document reserves a string to be used as a pseudo-TLD for non-DNS resolution contexts. However, it is clear that there is a significant need for a similar string to be used for namespaces which are resolved using the DNS protocol but which do not have a meaning in the global context.

There are no protocol police, and so there is no way to prevent users from simply picking a string (such as .home) and starting to use it for internal use. [ While it may be tempting to scold such users with a rolled up newspaper and shout "Bad user! Don't do that!", this is a: not really feasible and b: many times the users have a legitimate need for namespaces not connected to the global DNS. ] Unfortunately, while these strings are supposed to only be used internally, it is inevitable that they will leak into the global DNS.

This document requests allocation of a string to be used as a pseudo-TLD for namespaces that are not part of the global DNS. A reasonable analogy is that this is to names as RFC1918 is to IP addresses. This should alleviate pollution, such as junk queries at the root, and potential collisions with other users of the namespace.

[ Ed: Yes, I am well aware of the discussion of the .homenet delegation, and the resulting decision to *not* request that the IANA / ICANN / <someone> delegate the .homenet TLD for the IETF's use. There *are* significant similarities to the .homenet case, but also significant differences. These include (in no particular order) the fact that the use case is significant broader, and that there is no urgency to the request and does not delay or create uncertainty for any protocol work. No doubt there will be much discussion on the similarities, differences, precedent, etc. ]

section.title: Requirements notation
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .

section.title: Use cases
section.t: The ".internal" TLD can be used for any purpose where a non-global DNS name is needed.

This includes creating a namespace "behind" a Customer Premises Equipment (CPE) (for example, Belkin squatted on ".belkin" for this, British Telecom squatted on ".home", and shipped devices named "bthomehub.home" ), as well as internal resolution systems like Microsoft Active Directory (at one time, documentation suggested that administrators use ".corp" for this).
The .internal TLD is intended to address some of the issues documented in the Special-Use Domain Names Problem Statement specifically (from the list in Section 3):

list.t: Intended use is covered by gTLD process, but the third party doesn't want to pay a fee.
Intended use is covered by some IETF process, but the third party doesn't want to follow the process.
Unaware that a name intended to be used only locally may nevertheless leak
Unaware that a name used locally with informal allocation may subsequently be allocated formally, creating operational problems.
There exists no safe, non-process-violating mechanism for ad-hoc assignment of Special-Use Domain Names.

section.t: Other use cases for .internal include things like testing, prototyping and benchmarking - the author has often needed to setup a fake root and namespace in order to test something, and / or arbitrarily chosen a name for a piece of network equipment which it not connected to the Internet.

section.title: Why not use <existing name>?
section.t: The IANA "Special Use Names" registry [TODO: Ref] already contains some names which, it could be argued, already meet this need. Unfortunately, many of these names are either reserved for a specific use case (e.g .example), or are semantically unsuitable (for example, a CPE manufacturer would likely not find "Open a browser and connect to 'router.invalid'" acceptable).
This section discusses why existing strings in the Special-Use Domain Names registry () are not appropriate.

section.title: Why not use .alt?
section.t: The .alt presudo-TLD is specifically only for use as a pseudo-TLD for non-DNS resolution contexts. At one point .alt was being considered both for DNS and non-DNS resolution contexts, but, after much discussion it was decided that the DNSSEC implications (and desired behavior) meant that .alt should be reserved specifically for non-DNS resolution.

section.title: Why not use something.arpa?
section.t: This is indeed an interesting idea. I suspect that it fails the semantically desirable / understandable case, but is definitely worth discussing further. It may also cause issues when server operators override part of the .arpa domain in order to instantiate something.arpa.

section.title: Why not use .local?
section.t: .local is already in wide use and has special handling implemented for handing .local names. See Section 22.1 Subsection 3, 4, 5.

section.title: Why not use .example?
section.t: .example, .example.[com|net|org] may indeed be appropriate. Unfortunately, the hard part of all of this is not the selection and adding of a name to the "Special Use Names" registry, but rather a: deciding if this should be done, and b: process work to interact with ICANN in order to achieve the delegation.

section.title: DNSSEC Considerations
section.t: The .internal TLD would be an unsigned TLD, as there is no (clean) way to sign it.

This particular topic received much discussion during the "Should .alt be used for DNS, or only non-DNS resolution" discussions, and was the cause of much confusion and misunderstandings. Much of this revolved around why it is important to have an insecure DNSSEC delegation for a name which is added to the Locally-Served DNS Zones ( ) registry, or any other case where a name is instantiated. It is briefly covered here, but interested readers should review the DNSOP mailing lists for more details.

The user has just purchased a new CPE, which creates an internal namespace called .internal, and responds to lookups for router.interal with its (internal) management IP address (another example would be a corporate user at an organization which has created a private internal namespace disconnected from the public, global DNS). The CPE hands out addresses using DHCP, and lists itself as the DNS server.

The user follows the instructions included in the box, and enters "http://router.internal" into a web browser. This causes a DNS lookup to be sent from the user's stub to the recursive resolver. The recursive resolver correctly identifies that this is query is for itself, and so responds with an answer saying "router.internal is 192.168.0.1".

section.title: Scenario 1 - No DNSSEC, .internal not delegated
section.t: In this scenario, the .internal name has not been added to the root, and the user's stub resolver *does not* perform DNSSEC validation. The stub receives the response, performs no validation, and so trust the answer and connects. The user is happy. This is the current behavior for non-DNSSEC validating stubs.

section.title: Scenario 2 - DNSSEC, .internal not delegated
section.t: In this scenario, the .internal name has not been added to the root, and the user's stub resolver *does* perform DNSSEC validation. The stub receives the response, and begins DNSSEC validation. As the .internal TLD has not been added to the root zone, DNSSEC Authenticated Denial of Existence proves that the .internal TLD does not exist (currently there is an NSEC record proving that nothing exists between .intel and .international). This results is a DNSSEC Bogus outcome, the user is unable to connect, and becomes frustrated. This is the current behavior for DNSSEC validating stubs.

section.title: Scenario 3 - DNSSEC, .internal delegated
section.t: In this scenario, the .internal name has been added to the DNS root, with an insecure delegation to AS112 (by "insecure delegation" we mean that that there is no DS record for .internal in the root zone; the .internal domain is unsigned). The stub receives the response, and performs DNSSEC validation. As .internal has been delegated, there is an (insecure) entry in the root zone, proving that the .internal TLD exists. As it is an insecure delegation, the validating stub is perfectly happy to accept the "router.internal is 192.168.0.1" response, the user connects to their router, and everyone is happy.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This document requests that the .internal TLD be assigned to the IANA (like .example is) and a DNSSEC insecure delegation (no DS records) be inserted into the root-zone, delegated to blackhole-[12].iana.org [Ed: Oh, goody. We get to have the AS112 / DNAME / etc argument all over again! ]

[Ed note: I fully understand that this is not something which the IANA has the authority to do - this was extensively discussed during the .homenet discussions. The text in the IANA considerations is basically a placeholder. If there is consensus that the reservation of .internal makes sense, there will need to be a significant amount of process design. It is likely that this will look something like the IESG asks the IAB to request ICANN to consider the reservation / delegation of this string. ICANN does not currently have a process for handling requests like these, and so will likely need to design a process for this. It is expected that this will all be a lengthy process; it is also entirely possible that this may not actually result in a delegation. ]

section.title: Domain Name Reservation Considerations
section.t: [ Ed: This section is to satisfy the requirement in Section 5 of RFC6761. This document is intended to spark discussion, there is currently no process for the IETF / IAB to request that ICANN delegate a TLD for special use, and simply adding .internal to the "Special-Use Domain Name" registry () doesn't accomplish this. I have decided to fill in the RFC6761 "questions" simply to clarify the expected behavior. This entire section to be removed before publication. ]

The string ".internal." is special in the following ways: Users may know that strings that end in .internal behave differently to normal DNS names. They may expect that names of the form <something>.internal refer to resources internal to their network / enterprise / similar.
Writers of application software not required to perform any special handing for .internal names. They are resolved normally, using the DNS.
Writers of name resolution APIs and libraries are not expected to perform special handling.
Caching DNS servers MAY recognize these names as special. By default they should answer them locally (using "Locally Served Zones"), but may be configured to forward them to authoritative servers.
Authoritative DNS servers SHOULD NOT recognize these names as special and should not perform any special handling with them, unless they wish to instantiate an internal namespace, in which case they can choose to simply create any names within .internal that they want. Names are "local" to the network, and only have meaning within that network.
DNS server operators SHOULD be aware that queries for names ending in .internal are not part of the global, IANA DNS, and were leaked into the global DNS. This information may be useful for support or debugging purposes.
DNS Registries/Registrars MUST NOT grant requests to register ".internal" names in the normal way to any person or entity. These ".internal" names are defined by protocol specification to be nonexistent, and they fall outside the set of names available for allocation by registries/registrars.
